Triggering Event: In her decades-long career, she'd interviewed countless politicians and CEOs, but none had ever infuriated her more than this one. As he smugly dismissed her question about his company's layoffs as "fake news," she felt a familiar scorn rise within her. The contempt was palpable, but she kept it hidden behind a steely glare and a composed voice, saving her true reaction for the moment she walked out of the room, slamming the door behind her.
Generated Assessment: She remembered how many times she’d witnessed politicians downplaying scandals while CEOs flaunted their wealth. But there’s always another one who makes her feel like an idiot compared to them—someone who could’ve made her look bad if they hadn’t been so incompetent themselves. She just wanted to shake her head and tell herself that everyone has their own set of problems, but deep down, she couldn’t help feeling a little bitter. After all, she knew she wasn’t perfect either; she’d struggled with her own demons in the past, which still lingered. It was unfair to compare herself to these people who seemed to have it all together, especially when some of them were known for their shady dealings. Still, she couldn’t help but wonder what it would be like to sit across from someone who didn't pretend to be above criticism, someone who actually listened and tried to understand the struggles of everyday people. Maybe then she wouldn’t feel so left behind. But until then, she’ll keep asking tough questions, even if it means facing my own flaws head-on.
